hints.content:
###Strategy

In order to graph our absolute value function $f$, we need to find its vertex and any other point on the graph.

To find the vertex, we can use the most basic absolute value function $y = |x|$, which is graphed below.  The graph of $f$ is the result of moving this graph up/down or left/right. 

Once we have the vertex of the graph of $f$, we can find any other point by plugging-in some $x$-value into $f(x)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b9b8f4b4dac19e1197e9dd94553d0822f9fe69a.png)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x+4|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $4$ units to the left.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $4$ units to the left gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+4|$, which is $(-4,0)$.   
[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/588ad95c13cb682e12cc59a75bec8c2dd7bec79a)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x+4|+1$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x+4|$ moved up by $1$ unit. [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+4|$ up by $1$ unit gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+4|+1$, which is $(-4,1)$.   
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fc0dd3046956fa167f0fa12f9fb93d63da59ebe1)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a-4,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+4|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $4$ units to the left is the same as adding $-4$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x-4,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $4$ units to the left gives us the point $(0-4,0)=(-4,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+4|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+1)$ on the graph of $y=|x+4|+1$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $1$ unit is the same as adding $1$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+1)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+4|$ lies at $(-4,0)$, moving it up by $1$ unit gives us the point $(-4,0+1)=(-4,1)$.

hints.content:
###Graphing the function

**We've found that the vertex of $f$ is $(-4,1)$, and we can check that $(0,5)$ is a point that also lies on its graph.** [[☃ explanation 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0ae34d49ef6d3ab17f924c616676b94c1a46e0cf)

options.explanation: Since $f(0)=|0+4|+1=5$, it follows that $(0,5)$ is a point on the graph of $f$.

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a-5,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+5|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $3$ units is the same as adding $3$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+3)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+5|$ lies at $(-5,0)$, moving it up by $3$ units gives us the point $(-5,0+3)=(-5,3)$.

###Graphing the function

**We've found that the vertex of $f$ is $(-5,3)$, and we can check that $(0,8)$ is a point that also lies on its graph.** [[☃ explanation 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d601bf241ba6009afec7a7173eae5e6aee3dab0c)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x+2|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $2$ units to the left.   [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $2$ units to the left gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+2|$, which is $(-2,0)$.

Now note that the graph of $y=|x+2|+6$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x+2|$ moved up by $6$ units.  [[☃ explanation 3]]

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a-2,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+2|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $2$ units to the left is the same as adding $-2$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x-2,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $2$ units to the left gives us the point $(0-2,0)=(-2,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+2|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+6)$ on the graph of $y=|x+2|+6$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $6$ units is the same as adding $6$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+6)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+2|$ lies at $(-2,0)$, moving it up by $6$ units gives us the point $(-2,0+6)=(-2,6)$.

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x+1|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $1$ unit to the left.    [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $1$ unit to the left gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+1|$, which is $(-1,0)$.

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a-1,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+1|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $1$ unit to the left is the same as adding $-1$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x-1,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $1$ unit to the left gives us the point $(0-1,0)=(-1,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+1|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+5)$ on the graph of $y=|x+1|+5$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $5$ units is the same as adding $5$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+5)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+1|$ lies at $(-1,0)$, moving it up by $5$ units gives us the point $(-1,0+5)=(-1,5)$.

hints.content:
###Strategy

In order to graph our absolute value function $f$, we need to find its vertex and any other point on the graph.

To find the vertex, we can use the most basic absolute value function $y = |x|$, which is graphed below.  The graph of $f$ is the result of moving this graph up/down or left/right. 

Once we have the vertex of the graph of $f$, we can find any other point by plugging-in some $x$-value into $f(x)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b9b8f4b4dac19e1197e9dd94553d0822f9fe69a.png)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x-2|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $2$ units to the right.   [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $2$ units to the right gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|$, which is $(2,0)$. 
[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e480f54b06a4fba510d0cdee1311dbfce648cac3)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x-2|+2$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x-2|$ moved up by $2$ units. [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|$ up by $2$ units gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|+2$, which is $(2,2)$.
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/af42baa5297c5e544d8559c14ae6df02856c7408)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a+2,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-2|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $2$ units to the right is the same as adding $2$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x+2,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $2$ units to the right gives us the point $(0+2,0)=(2,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-2|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+2)$ on the graph of $y=|x-2|+2$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $2$ units is the same as adding $2$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+2)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-2|$ lies at $(2,0)$, moving it up by $2$ units gives us the point $(2,0+2)=(2,2)$.

hints.content:
###Strategy

In order to graph our absolute value function $f$, we need to find its vertex and any other point on the graph.

To find the vertex, we can use the most basic absolute value function $y = |x|$, which is graphed below.  The graph of $f$ is the result of moving this graph up/down or left/right. 

Once we have the vertex of the graph of $f$, we can find any other point by plugging-in some $x$-value into $f(x)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b9b8f4b4dac19e1197e9dd94553d0822f9fe69a.png)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x-3|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $3$ units to the right. 
  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $3$ units to the right gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-3|$, which is $(3,0)$.  
[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/71ed455f87ea3e6731f004103c9cb1af17d23fb2)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x-3|+4$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x-3|$ moved up by $4$ units.  [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-3|$ up by $4$ units gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-3|+4$, which is $(3,4)$.
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1c0aa8e814db78ee412e2cb0a31b6c7f03cde198)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a+3,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-3|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $3$ units to the right is the same as adding $3$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x+3,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $3$ units to the right gives us the point $(0+3,0)=(3,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-3|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+4)$ on the graph of $y=|x-3|+4$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $4$ units is the same as adding $4$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+4)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-3|$ lies at $(3,0)$, moving it up by $4$ units gives us the point $(3,0+4)=(3,4)$.

This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-1|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+3)$ on the graph of $y=|x-1|+3$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $3$ units is the same as adding $3$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+3)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-1|$ lies at $(1,0)$, moving it up by $3$ units gives us the point $(1,0+3)=(1,3)$.

[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e412b4ef82dc946efc7a07909dc7f8a64d0584fd)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x-1|+5$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x-1|$ moved up by $5$ units.  [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-1|$ up by $5$ units gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-1|+5$, which is $(1,5)$.
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a2305cc7cc43986f3b21421e3a6212180b95148c)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a+1,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-1|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $1$ unit to the right is the same as adding $1$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x+1,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $1$ unit to the right gives us the point $(0+1,0)=(1,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-1|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b+5)$ on the graph of $y=|x-1|+5$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ up by $5$ units is the same as adding $5$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y+5)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-1|$ lies at $(1,0)$, moving it up by $5$ units gives us the point $(1,0+5)=(1,5)$.

options.explanation: Since $f(0)=|0-1|+5=6$, it follows that $(0,6)$ is a point on the graph of $f$.

hints.content:
###Strategy

In order to graph our absolute value function $f$, we need to find its vertex and any other point on the graph.

To find the vertex, we can use the most basic absolute value function $y = |x|$, which is graphed below.  The graph of $f$ is the result of moving this graph up/down or left/right. 

Once we have the vertex of the graph of $f$, we can find any other point by plugging-in some $x$-value into $f(x)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b9b8f4b4dac19e1197e9dd94553d0822f9fe69a.png)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x-4|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $4$ units to the right. 
  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $4$ units to the right gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-4|$, which is $(4,0)$. 
[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7cb2f841680dfba63cfa67c84c350d2b9728ec08)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x-4|-5$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x-4|$ moved down by $5$ units.  [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-4|$ down by $5$ units gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-4|-5$, which is $(4,-5)$.  
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/91208b64d79864e3a54d5cf7e29e4824dc10d241)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a+4,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-4|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $4$ units to the right is the same as adding $4$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x+4,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $4$ units to the right gives us the point $(0+4,0)=(4,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x-4|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b-5)$ on the graph of $y=|x-4|-5$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ down by $5$ units is the same as adding $-5$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y-5)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x-4|$ lies at $(4,0)$, moving it down by $5$ units gives us the point $(4,0-5)=(4,-5)$.

First, note that the graph of $y=|x+6|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $6$ units to the left.

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $6$ units to the left gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+6|$, which is $(-6,0)$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ down by $4$ units is the same as adding $-4$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y-4)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+6|$ lies at $(-6,0)$, moving it down by $4$ units gives us the point $(-6,0-4)=(-6,-4)$.

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $2$ units to the left gives us the point $(0-2,0)=(-2,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+2|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b-8)$ on the graph of $y=|x+2|-8$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ down by $8$ units is the same as adding $-8$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y-8)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+2|$ lies at $(-2,0)$, moving it down by $8$ units gives us the point $(-2,0-8)=(-2,-8)$.

hints.content:
###Graphing the function

**We've found that the vertex of $f$ is $(-2,-8)$, and we can check that $(0,-6)$ is a point that also lies on its graph.** [[☃ explanation 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/88ef16c45eb901cf3710696d505b5db59b8eac64)

options.explanation: Since $f(0)=|0+2|-8=-6$, it follows that $(0,-6)$ is a point on the graph of $f$.

hints.content:
###Strategy

In order to graph our absolute value function $f$, we need to find its vertex and any other point on the graph.

To find the vertex, we can use the most basic absolute value function $y = |x|$, which is graphed below.  The graph of $f$ is the result of moving this graph up/down or left/right. 

Once we have the vertex of the graph of $f$, we can find any other point by plugging-in some $x$-value into $f(x)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b9b8f4b4dac19e1197e9dd94553d0822f9fe69a.png)

###Finding the vertex of the graph of $f$

Let's find the vertex by observing how we can move from the graph of $y=|x|$ to the graph of $f$. 

First, note that the graph of $y=|x+7|$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x|$  moved $7$ units to the left.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$  by $7$ units to the left gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+7|$, which is $(-7,0)$. 
[[☃ explanation 2]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b1ecc10bc4f881d962f93a51fa34d55fb22eff65)

Now note that the graph of $y=|x+7|-1$ is the same as the graph of $y=|x+7|$ moved down by $1$ unit.      [[☃ explanation 3]]

Therefore, moving the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+7|$ down by $1$ unit gives us the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+7|-1$, which is $(-7,-1)$.
[[☃ explanation 4]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6ed6d90acfad477026b8c837516100beeb5e18f6)

options.explanation: This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x|$ corresponds to the point $(a-7,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+7|$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ by $7$ units to the left is the same as adding $-7$ to its $x$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x-7,y)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x|$ lies at $(0,0)$, moving it $7$ units to the left gives us the point $(0-7,0)=(-7,0)$.
This is because any point $(a,b)$ on the graph of $y=|x+7|$ corresponds to the point $(a,b-1)$ on the graph of $y=|x+7|-1$.

Moving any point $(x,y)$ down by $1$ unit is the same as adding $-1$ to its $y$-coordinate. That is to say, the moved point has coordinates $(x,y-1)$. 

Since the vertex of the graph of $y=|x+7|$ lies at $(-7,0)$, moving it down by $1$ unit gives us the point $(-7,0-1)=(-7,-1)$.
